references: We conducted experiments on a total of nine datasets retrieved from MoleculeNet¬†[57] for molecular property prediction, including four regression datasets (FreeSolv, Lipophilicity, ESOL, and QM9) and five classification datasets (Tox21, SIDER, ClinTox, BBBP, and BACE). We follow the prediction tasks in [57] and summarize the statistics for all datasets in Table 1.

references: The experimental results on regression and classification datasets are shown in Table 2 and Table 3 respectively. We draw several points according to the results. First, comparing our centralized training results (denoted as FedChem) with MolNet¬†[57], we obtain competitive results by using MPNNs2s¬†[14] and SchNet¬†[48]. Specifically, we obtain a significant performance gain by adopting SchNet for QM9 dataset¬†[48]. Second, comparing the performance of FedAvg with different Œ±ùõº\alpha for each dataset, we can conclude that the heterogeneity settings introduced by FedChem indeed lead to performance degradation for 7 out of 9 datasets (i.e., FreeSolv, ESOL, QM9, Tox21, ClinTox, BBBP, and BACE). FedAvg shows stable performance for Lipophilicity and SIDER. The reason may be that we do not consider the relation between scaffold subgroups in our current settings, and the resulted clients‚Äô datasets are rather homogeneous. Third, we observe a significant performance gain for most datasets by comparing heterogeneous federated learning methods with FedAvg. For example, the proposed FLIP+ achieves a 0.543 improvement with Œ±=0.1ùõº0.1\alpha=0.1 and 0.162 improvement with Œ±=1ùõº1\alpha=1 for FreeSolv. The results suggest the necessity to mitigate the heterogeneity when conducting federated learning and validate the effectiveness of the proposed FLIT(+). However, we also observe that the performance improvements of our methods are rather marginal for several datasets. The reasons may be attributed to the fact that our current scaffold splitting may not lead to heterogeneous datasets. We will continue our work for a better method to simulate the heterogeneity problem for federated molecular property prediction.
